body_html: "Low-performance" is a bit of an over-simplification. Improvements in TensorFlow performance translates directly to datacenter cost savings, so Google spends significant resources in this area. What's happening is that some kinds of computations are optimized, while others, especially ones small enough to run in Matlab, are not. I think eventually, most computations will be possible to do in TensorFlow without incurring high performance/human cost, but what can help in getting there faster is providing self-contained benchmarks that demonstrate the problem.
